nodes.name: Quality
nodes.description:
Quality is inversely proportional to variability
Quality is not a program; it is an approach to business
Quality is a collection of powerful tools and concepts that are proven to work
Quality is defined by customers through their satisfaction
Quality includes continual improvement and breakthrough events
Quality tools and techniques are applicable in every aspect of business
Quality is aimed at perfection; anything less is an improvement opportunity
Quality increases customer satisfaction, reduces cycle time and costs, and eliminates errors and rework

nodes.name: six sigma
nodes.description:
a method of reaching 99.9998% of conformance when a 1.5σ shift where only 3.4 ppm fail to meet specifications.
Six Sigma depends on successfully integrating two components: strategy and metrics.
no more than 3.4 defects per million parts or process steps if the process mean were to shift by as much as 1.5σ

nodes.name: Walter A. Shewhart
nodes.description:
A. Shewhart altered the course of industrial history by bringing 
together the disciplines of statistics, engineering, and economics.

nodes.name: Statistical process control (SPC)
nodes.description: Statistical process control is for a process that it is in statistical control.

nodes.name: Economic Control of Quality of Manufactured Product
Pareto diagram (chart)
nodes.description:
The purpose of a Pareto chart is to identify those “vital few” areas that account for the largest frequency or relative frequency in a data set and separate them from 
the “trivial many.”
A Pareto chart graphically depicts the “80/20 rule”
Number of defects vs. types of defects to find the vital few.

nodes.name: Juran Trilogy
nodes.description:
1. Quality control
	monitoring techniques to correct sporadic problems (analogous to special causes)
2. Quality improvement
	a breakthrough sequence to solve chronic problems (analogous to common causes)
3. Quality planning
	an annual quality program to institutionalize managerial control and review

nodes.name: Quality planning
nodes.description: Quality planning is a strategic activity that involves identifying the needs of the customer.

nodes.name: Periodic work review
nodes.description:
An opportunity for the project leader and the sponsor of the project to discuss progress
A summary of performance (presuming day-to-day feedback was given), evaluation of progress, determination of actions to correct/ improve performance, and renegotiation of such activities as may be necessary
An assessment documentation relative to the work objectives
An effective time for the manager to reinforce work done well, assuming 
the work climate is conducive to frank, open, two-way discussion and problem solving
An effective time for the sponsor to provide input on the project and assist with elevating to upper management any issues/concerns regarding the project

nodes.name: Monitoring and Measuring Project Activity and Results
Project Documentation
nodes.description:
• Assumptions, risks, and rationale for selecting the project
• Decisions made to initiate project and approvals
• Detailed plans for design and implementation
• Design and/or implementation changes
• Major obstacles encountered and how they were resolved
• Details of implementation (e.g., measurements established)
• Progress reports and resulting decisions
• Risk log
• Budget information
• Scope changes
• Final evaluation of project results
• Results of post-project audits

nodes.name: QIS
nodes.description: the quality information system collect, store, analyze, and manage quality-related data from customers, suppliers, and internal processes.

nodes.name: CODE OF ETHICS
nodes.description: The ASQ Code of Ethics emphasizes that quality engineers are professionals and must act accordingly. Federal law and employer rules create additional requirements for compliance. You must understand all of the above and more as it is presented to you.

nodes.name: Act with Integrity and Honesty
nodes.description:
1. Strive to uphold and advance the integrity, honor, and dignity of the Quality profession .
2. Be truthful and transparent in all professional interactions and activities.
3. Execute professional responsibilities and make decisions in an objective, factual, and fully informed manner.
4. Accurately represent and do not mislead others regarding professional qualifications, including education, titles, affiliations, and certifications. 
5. Offer services, provide advice, and undertake assignments only in your areas of competence, expertise, and training.

nodes.name: Demonstrate Responsibility, Respect, and Fairness
nodes.description:
1. Hold paramount the safety, health, and welfare of individuals, the public, and the environment.
2. Avoid conduct that unjustly harms or threatens the reputation of the Society, its members, or the Quality profession.
3. Do not intentionally cause harm to others through words or deeds. Treat others fairly, courteously, with dignity, and without prejudice or discrimination.
4. Act and conduct business in a professional and socially responsible manner.
5. Allow diversity in the opinions and personal lives of others.

nodes.name: Safeguard Proprietary Information and Avoid Conflicts of Interest
nodes.description:
1. Ensure the protection and integrity of confidential information.
2. Do not use confidential information for personal gain. 
3. Fully disclose and avoid any real or perceived conflicts of interest that could reasonably impair objectivity or independence in the service of clients, customers, employers, or the Society. 
4. Give credit where it is due.
5. Do not plagiarize. Do not use the intellectual property of others without permission. Document the permission as it is obtained.

nodes.description: refer to ASQ chapter 1 under the subject

nodes.name: supplier management
nodes.description:
8.4   Control of Externally Provided Processes, Products, and Services
8.4.1   General 
The organization shall ensure that externally provided processes, products, and services conform to requirements.
The organization shall be responsible for the conformity of all externally provided processes, products, and services, including from sources defined by the customer.
The organization shall ensure, when required, that customer-designated or approved external providers, including process sources (e.g., special processes), are used.
The organization shall identify and manage the risks associated with the external provision of processes, products, and services, as well as the selection and use of external providers.
The organization shall require that external providers apply appropriate controls to their direct and sub-tier external providers, to ensure that requirements are met.
The organization shall determine the controls to be applied to externally provided processes, products, and services when:
a.  products and services from external providers are intended for incorporation into the organization’s own products and 
services;
b.  products and services are provided directly to the customer(s) by external providers on behalf of the organization;
c.  a process, or part of a process, is provided by an external provider as a result of a decision by the organization.
The organization shall determine and apply criteria for the evaluation, selection, monitoring of performance, and re-evaluation of external providers, based on their ability to provide processes or products and services in accordance with requirements. The organization shall retain documented information of these activities and any necessary actions arising from the evaluations.

nodes.name: Variation
nodes.description: it is also defined as SD

nodes.name: Defect
nodes.description:
A defect is a nonconformity severe enough to cause the product not to satisfy normal usage requirements.
lack of fitness for use

nodes.name: nonconformity
nodes.description: A nonconformity is defined as a failure of a quality characteristic to meet a specification.

nodes.name: Inspection
nodes.description: Inspection is a process of measuring, examining, testing, gauging, or otherwise comparing a unit with the applicable requirements.

nodes.name: Source inspection
nodes.description:
Source inspection is the inspection of purchased parts at the supplier’s 
facility by a customer representative to ensure supplier compliance with 
specifications and contractual agreements.

nodes.name: Incoming Inspection
nodes.description: Incoming inspection is the inspection of purchased parts at the customer’s facility

nodes.name: Survey
nodes.description:
It is important that the team meet prior to arriving at the supplier’s facility. 
Based on the premise that the team has reviewed all pertinent materials, the presurvey meeting is held to (1) ensure that all of the team members agree on the theme and purpose of the survey, (2) ensure that the roles and responsibilities of each team member are understood by the others, (3) draft a preliminary survey 
agenda, and (4) select the team leader.

nodes.name: checklist
nodes.description:
1. Drawing and specification control
2. Purchased material control
3. Measuring and test equipment control
4. Process control and product acceptance
5. Material storage area, packing, shipping, and record retention control
6. Quality program management
7. Statistical process control
8. Strength summary of system evaluation
9. Corrective action summary of system evaluation
10. Summary report

nodes.name: report
nodes.description:
1. Type of audit conducted
2. Objectives of audit
3. Identification of involved parties: auditor, auditee, and third party
4. Audit team members
5. Critical nonconformities and other observations
6. Audit standards and reference documents used
7. Determination of proper corrective action(s)
8. Duration of audit
9. Audit report distribution and date
10. Audit results and recommendations
11. Audit-related records

nodes.name: barrier
nodes.description:
1. Lack of time to devote to quality initiatives.
2. Poor intra-organizational communication.
3. Lack of real employee empowerment. 
4. Lack of employee trust in senior management.
5. Politics and turf issues.
6. Lack of a formalized strategic plan for change.
7. Lack of strong motivation.
8. View of quality program as a quick fix.
9. Drive for short-term ficial results. 
10. Lack of leadership.
11. Lack of customer focus.
12. Lack of a company-wide definition of quality.

nodes.description:
• Definition phase.
• Specification phase.
• Concept phase. 
• Detailed design phase. 
• Prototype phase.
• Production phase. 
• Distribution phase. 
• Normal use phase. 
• Obsolescence and disposal phase.

One model for review of designs: the Systems Engineering Technical Review Process as described in the United States Navy, Naval Air Systems Command (NAVAIR) Instruction 4355.19E (February 2015).

nodes.description: Design for Reliability (DFR) is an approach to design that focuses on development of products and processes able to perform under specified conditions, in a specified environment, and for specified periods of time.

nodes.name: Quality tables
nodes.description:
A series of matrices used to translate the voice of the  customer into final product control characteristics.

1. Customer requirements planning matrix
2. Design matrix
3. Final product characteristic deployment matrix
4. Manufacturing/purchasing matrix
5. Process plan and quality control charts
6. Operating instructions
7. Human factor studies or surveys for capturing VOC

nodes.name: design review
nodes.description:
viewpoints:
• Reliability. Will the failure rate be sufficiently low?
• Quality engineering. Can the design be adequately inspected and tested?
• Field engineering. Are proper installation, maintece, and user-handling features included in the design?
• Procurement. Can the necessary parts be acquired at acceptable costs, delivery schedules, and quality levels?
• Materials engineering. Will the selected materials perform as expected?
• Tooling engineering. Is the equipment capable of meeting the specified tolerances on a consistent basis?
• Packaging engineering. Can the product be shipped without damage?
• Outside consultants. Have appropriate outside consultants been called for when necessary?
• Customer. Should a customer representative participate in the design reviews for military applications and original equipment manufacturers?
• Other design engineers. Are other design engineers needed when there are tight tolerances to mating components or critical system interfaces?

nodes.name: design validation
nodes.description: Design validation is the “confirmation, through the provision of objective evidence, that the requirements for a specific intended use or application have been fulfilled” (ISO 9000:2015)

nodes.name: Failure mode
nodes.description:
A failure mode is simply how a product or process can fail to meet its intended function or specifications. It's the way in which something can go wrong.
Failure modes can range from minor inconveniences to catastrophic events, depending on the context.

nodes.name: Reliability testing categories
nodes.description:
• Environmental stress screening to determine the capability of the 
product under different operating conditions and to help eliminate 
infant mortality failures
• Reliability growth tests performed periodically between design 
conception and final production to track gains in reliability
• Reliability qualification tests to provide assurance that production units 
will meet requirements when they become available
• Production reliability acceptance tests to periodically verify that 
production units meet specified reliability requirements and are 
acceptable for use

nodes.name: Process and product qualification
nodes.description:
Installation qualification (IQ), 
Operational qualification (OQ),
Process qualification (PQ)

nodes.name: type of Maintenance
nodes.description:
Corrective maintece
	no repairs, 
	No replacements
	No preventive maintece until failures
Preventive maintece
	When repair after failure is costly
	The failure rate is monotonically increasing with time.
Predictive maintece
	Minimize loss
	Only defective parts
	
	1. a condition parameter, 2. monitor it, 3. defining a limit

nodes.name: critical failure
nodes.description: that cause total interruption of the function or potential injuries to users

nodes.name: Control plan
nodes.description: to document and communicate the plan for monitoring and controlling the process.

nodes.name: Risk Priority Number (RPN)
nodes.description:
Severity: impact on end user
Likelihood (O)
Detection % (D)
RPN=S x O x D

nodes.name: UFMEA
nodes.description:
UFMEA analyzes the uses and misuses of the product or process and identifies 
the use errors and their effects and consequences.
UFMEA usually considers the usability and human 
factors for the product, process, or service and considers the user interaction with 
the system as a whole at preset locations per design of the system.

nodes.name: Control method
nodes.description: –x and R chart, check sheet, go/no-go, poka-yoke, etc.

nodes.name: poka-yoke
nodes.description: The poka-yoke method is used to prevent or detect errors.

nodes.name: reaction plan
nodes.description: defines what, where, and when to measure characteristics and how to reaction to them

nodes.name: Hazard analysis and critical control points (HACCP)
defect types
nodes.description:
Minor defects
	they may cause minor problems during normal use.
Major defects
	they may cause major problems during normal use. A major defect will likely result in reducing the usability of the product.
Serious defects
	They may lead to injury or significant economic loss.
Critical defects
	they may lead directly to severe injury or catastrophic economic loss.

nodes.name: acceptance sampling
nodes.description:
To distinguish between good lots/parts and bad lots/parts.
To determine the status of process control.
To evaluate process capability.
To determine process adjustment.
To rate the accuracy of inspectors.
To serve as a mechanism for evaluating vendors.

It is not advised for processes in continuous production and in a state of statistical control, Deming (1986).

nodes.name: sampling plan
nodes.description: For any single sampling plan, the plan is completely described by the lot size, sample size, and acceptance number.

nodes.name: OC curves
nodes.description:
the operating characteristic (OC) curve
OC curve; The probability of 
acceptance = f(lot#, n, c, number of nonconforming items)
each sampling plan has its own OC curve for each lot number, sample size, and acceptance number (c)

nodes.name: sampling method
nodes.description: sampling plans for attributes, sampling plans for variables, and special sampling plans.

nodes.name: OC curves types
nodes.description:
(1) type A OC curves and 
(2) type B OC curves. Type A OC curves are used to calculate the probability of acceptance on a lot-by-lot basis when the lot is not a product of a continuous process. These OC curves are calculated using the hypergeometric distribution.
Type B OC curves are used to evaluate sampling plans for a continuous process or for a process where a lot of size N is large.

nodes.name: Levels of Inspection
nodes.description:
inspection used in ANSI/ASQ Z1.4: initial, reduced inspection, 
normal inspection, tightened inspection, and four levels of special inspection.

nodes.name: gage
nodes.description: ages are used to determine the conformance or nonconformance of a dimension to required specifications without attempting actual measurements.

nodes.name: METROLOGY
nodes.description: that portion of measurement science that is often used to provide, maintain, and disseminate a consistent set of units, to provide support for the enforcement of equity in trade by weights and measurement laws, or to provide data for quality control in manufacturing (Simpson 1981).

nodes.name: Accuracy
nodes.description:
the degree of a measurement agreeing with an accepted reference
The three components of accuracy are bias, linearity, and stability.

nodes.name: Precision
nodes.description: Precision is the degree of mutual agreement among individual measurements made under prescribed like conditions, or simply, how well identically performed measurements agree with each other (Montgomery 2013).

nodes.name: systematic errors
nodes.description: systematically below or above the true value

nodes.name: Repeatability
nodes.description:
Repeatability represents the variability due to the gage or test instrument when used to measure the same part under identical conditions (i.e., same operator measuring the same part).
it is the square of (average of ranges for each part divided by the d2 of all data)

nodes.name: Reproducibility
nodes.description:
Reproducibility represents the variability due to different operators or setups measuring the same parts using the same measuring device. 
Reproducibility represents the variability due to the measurement system. Both repeatability and reproducibility will be discussed in more detail in this chapter.
it is the square of (range of the average of the operators divided by the SD of all data)

nodes.name: gage R&R
nodes.description:
to determine whether a measurement system is capable for its intended purpose. 
recommend at least five or six operators in a typical gage R&R study. (3 is okay, 10 samples, 3 replicate for each sample)
total variance is the sum of total gage variances (Gage R&R) plus the part-to-part variance.

nodes.name: Part-to-Part Variability
nodes.description: it is the square of ( range of average measurement for each part (Rp) divided by the SD of all data)

nodes.name: x bar chart
nodes.description: Each point on the x chart represents the average of the two measurements taken by an operator on a part.

nodes.name: R chart
nodes.description: Each point on the R chart represents the range between the two measurements taken by an operator on a part.

nodes.name: d2
nodes.description: Complete details of determining values of d2 for each of the above quantities can be found in AIAG (2010)

nodes.name: Quality control tools
nodes.description:
Quality control tools as defined by ASQ and as accepted throughout the quality engineering community include the following:
• Flowcharts
• Pareto charts
• Cause and effect diagrams
• Control charts
• Check sheets
• Scatter diagrams
• Histograms

nodes.name: Flowcharts
nodes.description: The purpose of a flowchart is to provide a graphical representation of the elements, components, or tasks associated with a process.

nodes.name: Check Sheets
nodes.description:
The purpose of a check sheet is to summarize, and in some cases graphically depict, a tally count of event occurrences.
the check sheet is a very simple tool for collecting organizing and analyzing data.

nodes.name: Cause and effect or fishbone diagram
8Ms or 6Ms
nodes.description:
head: the effect
main bones: 
• Man (people or personnel)
• Machines (hardware/equipment)
• Materials
• Methods
• Measurements
• Mother Nature (environment)
+
• Maintenance
• Management

nodes.name: Scatter diagram
nodes.description: defects vs a variable to find a correlation to identify the relationship

nodes.name: Histogram
nodes.description:
The purpose of a histogram is to graphically depict the frequency of occurrence of events, where event occurrences are sorted into categories of a defined range along 
a continuous scale. Histograms are helpful for displaying the distribution of event occurrences among the various columns or categories of event types.

nodes.name: Matrix diagram
nodes.description: The purpose of a matrix diagram is to help people discover, visualize, and communicate relationships within a single set of factors or between two or more sets of factors.

nodes.name: Affinity diagram
nodes.description: The purpose of an affinity diagram is to help people collect, organize, summarize, and communicate facts, opinions, and ideas.

nodes.name: Interrelationship diagram
nodes.description:
it is a graph similar to knowledge graph
the one with most lines in are the effect
the one with most line out is the cause

nodes.name: Prioritization matrix
nodes.description:
The purpose of a prioritization matrix is to help people measure/evaluate relationships from a matrix or tree analysis relative to a weighting scheme and decision criteria to set implementation priorities for the decisions at hand. 
Prioritization factors against criteria or importance

nodes.name: process decision program chart (PDPC)
nodes.description: (PDPC) is to help people organize and evaluate process-related events and contingencies with respect to implementation and/or early operations. The PDPC is useful in helping us proactively evaluate or assess process implementation at a high level, early in the planning stage, or in the initial start- up phases of process operations.

nodes.name: activity network diagram
nodes.description: identifying the critical path to do the activity

nodes.name: SIPOC diagram
nodes.description: The SIPOC diagram is a high- level process map used to identify the important aspects of the current process (an acronym for suppliers, inputs, process, outputs, and customers).

nodes.name: Kaizen
nodes.description:
1. Value-added and non-value-added work activities
2. Muda, which refers to the seven classes of waste: overproduction, delay, transportation, processing, inventory, wasted motion, and defective parts
3. Principles of motion study.
4. Principles of materials handling.
5. Documentation of standard operating procedures.
6. The five S’s for workplace organization, which are five Japanese words that mean proper arrangement (seiri), orderliness (seiton), personal cleanliness (seiso), cleanup (seiketsu), and discipline (shitsuke). 
7. Visual management by means of visual displays
8. Just-in-time principles to produce only the right units in the right quantities, at the right time, and with the right resources.
9. Poka-yoke to prevent or detect errors.
10. Team dynamics, which include problem solving, communication skills, and conflict resolution (Gee, McGrath, and Izadi 1996).

nodes.name: Muda
nodes.description:
waste is any activity that doesn't create value for customers.
Muda refers to the seven (or 8) classes of waste: Defective parts, Overproduction, Waiting (delay), (Non-utilize talent), Transportation, Inventory, wasted motion, and extra-processing.
DOWNTIME

nodes.name: 5 S
nodes.description:
The five S’s for workplace organization, which are five Japanese words that mean proper arrangement (seiri), orderliness (seiton), personal cleanliness (seiso), cleanup (seiketsu), and discipline (shitsuke). 
Seiri (Sort) – Eliminate that which is not needed
Seiton (Set) – Organize the remaining Items near point of use for ease of use
Seiso (Shine) – Clean and inspect the work area
Seiketsu (Standardize) – Create standards for previous 3 steps to ensure daily activity
Shitsuke (Sustain) – Regularly apply the 5S standards above
and added safety for the 6th one

nodes.name: Cp
nodes.description:
(USL -LSL)/6 sigma (this is R bar divided by d2, from SPC)
it is appropriate when the process is centered

nodes.name: Cpk
nodes.description:
it is the minimum of Cp,upper and Cp,lower.
it provides a measure of the fraction of conforming values.

nodes.name: Value Stream Map (VSM)
nodes.description: to document, analyze, communicate, and improve the end-to-end value stream associated with a product or service

nodes.name: Kanban
nodes.description: The method of a kanban ensures material is only produced when it’s needed and thus limits inventory and ensure that value is pulled through a system instead of pushed.

nodes.name: Standard Work (SOP)
nodes.description: describe the Who, What, When, Where, How and Why associated with the process.

nodes.name: Takt time
nodes.description: the time to produce a single unit to meet customer demand.

nodes.name: Single Minute Exchange of Die (SMED)
nodes.description: a technique for studying and reducing the time required to change over a machine.

nodes.name: Overall Equipment Effectiveness (OEE)
nodes.description:
OEE = Availability x Performance x Quality 
OEE is a rate metric that is calculated to determine how well a manufacturing unit, for example a machine, is operating when compared against its full potential in terms of operating time, performance, and quality performance.

nodes.name: the eight disciplines (8D) model
nodes.description:
D0:	Plan
D1:	Use a team
D2:	Define and describe the problem
D3:	Develop an interim containment plan
D4:	Determine, identify, and verify root causes and escape points
D5:	Choose and verify permanent corrections (PCs) for problem/ nonconformity
 D6:	Implement and validate corrective actions
D7: Take preventive measures
D8: Congratulate your team

nodes.name: measurement scale
nodes.description:
Nominal scales
	Nominal scales classify data into categories with no order
	Ex: list of equipment.
Ordinal scales
	Ordinal scales refer to positions in a series where order is important, but precise differences between values are not defined.
	Ex: Mohs Hardness values
Interval scales
	They have meaningful differences but no absolute zero. ratios are not meaningful. 
	Ex: temperature measured in degrees Fahrenheit, °F 
Ratio scales
	They have meaningful differences and an absolute zero exists.
	Ex: in and °K.

edges.name: support
edges.description:
10.3  Continual Improvement
The organization shall continually improve the suitability, adequacy, and effectiveness of the quality management system.
The organization shall consider the results of analysis and evaluation, and the outputs from management review, to determine if there are needs or opportunities that shall be addressed as part of continual improvement.
The organization shall monitor the implementation of improvement activities and evaluate the effectiveness of the results.
NOTE: Examples of continual improvement opportunities can include lessons learned, problem resolutions, and 
the benchmarking of best practices.

evaluate
edges.description:
1. Plan adequacy
	Does the plan adequately address strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats (SWOT)?
 2. Competitive advantage
	Will the plan result in a significant competitive advantage in the marketplace?
 3. Sustainable advantage
	Is this advantage sustainable?
 4. Employees mission and purpose
	Does the vision statement inspire a sense of mission and purpose among employees?
 5. SMART goals
	Are the goals and objectives SMART (specific, measurable, achievable, realistic, and time-based)?
 6. Organizational alignment
	Are the goals and objectives aligned throughout the organization?
 7. Resource adequacy
	Have adequate resources been allocated to achieve the plan?
 8. Organization structure
	Are organizational structures, systems, and processes appropriate to execute the plan?
 9. Monitor
	Is a review/reporting system in place to monitor the execution of the plan?
 10. Team of stakeholders
	Does the strategic planning team include representatives from all key stakeholders?

edges.name: is a
edges.description:
1. Define Scope and Objectives:

Clearly define the product, process, or system that will be analyzed.
Establish the objectives of the FMEA. What are you trying to achieve? (e.g., improve reliability, reduce defects, enhance safety)
2. Form a Cross-Functional Team:

Assemble a team with diverse expertise relevant to the area being analyzed (e.g., design, manufacturing, quality, testing).
This ensures a comprehensive understanding of potential failure modes and their impact.
3. Identify Potential Failure Modes:

Brainstorm all the ways in which the product or process could fail to meet its intended function or specifications.
Consider various perspectives and use techniques like brainstorming, historical data analysis, and fault tree analysis.
4. Determine Failure Effects:

For each identified failure mode, determine the potential consequences or effects it could have on the product, process, customer, or environment.
Consider both internal and external effects.
5. Assess Severity:

Evaluate the severity of each failure effect on a scale (e.g., 1 to 10, with 1 being minor and 10 being catastrophic).
This helps prioritize failure modes based on their potential impact.
6. Estimate Occurrence:

Estimate the likelihood or frequency of each failure mode occurring.
Use historical data, expert judgment, or other relevant information to assign an occurrence rating (e.g., 1 to 10, with 1 being rare and 10 being frequent).
7. Evaluate Detection:

Assess the ability of current controls or methods to detect each failure mode before it results in significant consequences.
Assign a detection rating (e.g., 1 to 10, with 1 being certain detection and 10 being no detection).
8. Calculate Risk Priority Number (RPN):

Calculate the RPN for each failure mode by multiplying the severity, occurrence, and detection ratings: RPN = Severity x Occurrence x Detection.
The RPN provides a numerical ranking of failure modes, allowing for prioritization of those with the highest risk.
9. Develop Action Plans:

For the highest-priority failure modes (those with high RPNs), develop action plans to mitigate or eliminate the risks.
This may involve design changes, process improvements, enhanced controls, or other preventive measures.
10. Implement and Verify Actions:

Implement the action plans and verify their effectiveness in reducing the likelihood or impact of the identified failure modes.
This may involve testing, monitoring, and data analysis.
11. Review and Update:

Regularly review and update the FMEA as needed to reflect changes in the product, process, or system, or as new failure modes are identified.
FMEA is an ongoing process of continuous improvement.

govern
edges.description:
8.1.4 note
also as per 8.4.1   General 
The organization shall ensure that externally provided processes, products, and services conform to requirements.
The organization shall be responsible for the conformity of all externally provided processes, products, and services, including from sources defined by the customer.
The organization shall ensure, when required, that customer-designated or approved external providers, including process sources (e.g., special processes), are used.
The organization shall identify and manage the risks associated with the external provision of processes, products, and services, as well as the selection and use of external providers.
The organization shall require that external providers apply appropriate controls to their direct and sub-tier external providers, to ensure that requirements are met.
also 8.4.1.1
also 8.4.3   Information for External Providers

0. Defining the Scale, Severity, Occurrence and Detection levels
And, acceptable level of RPN
1. Identify a starting point for the analysis.
2. Gather all relevant inputs to support the analysis.
	creating a functional block diagram, a process flow diagram or a boundary diagram
3. Identify potential failure modes
4. Quantify the risk associated with each potential failure
5. Develop a corrective action plan
6. Repeat the analysis until all potential failures pose an acceptable level of risk.
7. Document results.
8. Report-out and/or present results.
